reviews.review:
Wow, what a ride...

I played this game back in 99, not long after it came out. I was too young to appreciate this gem back then (plus I got noobishly stuck on the 2nd chapter), but I decided to come back to it after 20(!) years. It was one of the best decisions I've made. This game not only holds up to modern day standards. It has an atmosphere that is simply irreplicable. 
Nice visuals, great story, groundbreaking physics engine for its time and most importantly tons of fun! Must have!

This game came out the day I was born, and is universally loved. As it got older, it made people feel a sense of wasted potential with no story arc coming to a close. Like me, it disappointed so many.

I have an opinion about this and Half-Life 2 that is both popular and unpopular. I think Half-Life 2 is better than this, but by a much larger margin than how other people think about these two games.

Of my experience with this game, three quarters of it was very fun. Shooting aliens, walking fast, picking up new guns, killing an entire military force, it was slightly harder than Half-Life 2 but I didn't care. In a way it kind of made it more fun. Then the last quarter of my experience with this game was filled with the most frustrating crap any game has thrown at me. This is the most frustrated I have ever been with a game in my short life. I did beat it twice, and my second playthrough was much better than my first, but holy god my first playthrough was hell. Many of the countless deaths I had were my fault, but there were some that were not. Why do the HECU's grenades sometimes decide to explode quicker than other times? Why is it that when you're anywhere within an explosion's radius, it does three quarters of your health of damage at the very least. Why is fall damage so damn sensitive? Why do grenades explode instantly whenever you throw them against a wall in front of you? Why do they sometimes instantly explode on nothing?

Some negatives I have that aren't related to dying: what's with the end of the game having so many vortigaunts? It's not like they're the most interesting enemy in the world...

But I still loved this game. I'm sure that the more I play it, the more I'll like it. That's how it went for me in Half-Life 2. Speaking of Half-Life 2, this does actually do some things better. More enemy variety, weapon variety, you actually get ammo for the magnum and crossbow, I like the sounds and visuals in Xen, the game was still as enjoyable, even if I was about to destroy my computer at a few select parts. This game gets a recommend and a 7/10 from me.

Many classic games just don't hold up anymore. Some haven't aged well; others have had their ideas done better by later games. Many of gaming's most influential games simply aren't that good by today's standards. Unfortunately, Half Life 1 is one of those games.

Half Life can mostly be broken up into two kinds of gameplay sections. The first kind of gameplay section is made up of environmental puzzle solving with some light horror elements. These sections are quite good. You walk around the mostly empty halls of the facility, solving environmental puzzles while keeping an eye out for vortigaunts and zombies hidden around corners, in cupboards, behind debris, and etc. The levels are well designed, the puzzles cleverly use real-world rules and solutions (such as live wires electrifying puddles of water), and the occasional jump scare from a vortigaunt or zombie keeps you on your toes.

The second kind of gameplay section is more typically FPS fare - fast-paced action segments in which you square off against special ops forces with guns, turrets, grenades, and etc. This is where the game really stumbles. The movement feels slidey and imprecise. Enemies almost always have hitscan weapons with large magazines, which means sticking your head out from cover to fire back almost always results in unavoidable damage. Your arsenal of weapons is reasonably large but feels small, as several guns are outright better than others in fulfilling the same role. Worst of all, enemies feel far too spongey; a point-blank shotgun blast to the chest will regularly fail to kill even standard grunt enemies.

Taken all together, these grievances result in FPS action sections which just feel bad to play. As I played through these sections, the thought most often at the front of my mind was "I can't wait for this to end so I can go back to a section of environmental puzzle solving." Unfortunately, as the game progresses, the FPS action sections get longer and more frequent, and the enjoyable parts of the game, the environmental puzzle sections, get fewer and farther between. Towards the end of my play time with Half Life, I was thoroughly fed up with it and just wanted it to be over.

Half Life was probably a great game when it came out, and it certainly had an influence on its genre going forward. However, over the two decades since its release, significant portions of the game have not aged very well, and no longer provide a satisfying experience when compared to today's standards. Though the environmental puzzle solving sections are still pretty good, the FPS action sections simply do not provide satisfying gunfights anymore.

Great game, fun adventure, surprisingly good soundtrack, ugly graphics but to be expected by the age. 9/10

Ask anyone over a certain age who actively plays games, knows about games and/or works in the industry to count the top 10 arguably even the top 5 most 'important' games of ALL time and I guarantee you 1998's Half-Life in all likelihood will be in one of those lists. Why? Because it was a game-changer. And also no Half-Life = no Steam on which you're reading this.

Prior to Half-Life, those of us who were lucky or privileged enough to own a decent PC back in the 90's had Doom and then a proper 3-D First-Person Shooter in the form of Quake a few years later. Both of which are classic games in their own right but they were mainly aim and blast FPS with not much in the way of 'feel', depth, structure or narrative. They were created for basic quick-fire fun and not much else and no, that's not a critism. 

Half-Life then comes along with a main protagonist by the name of Gordon Freeman and a brilliant setting in the way of a secret military installation called Black Mesa. (Area 51 entering mainstream pop culture in the 90's thanks mainly to the X-Files and Independence Day). Both of those things are then bound together with what was then, an EPIC sized map! What I loved and still love about this game is that it had attitude. And it happily let the player know this right from the very start with the 'then' stunning real-time rendered intro sequence. Unlike the fashion at the time, no pre-rendered CGI cut-scenes were to be seen here. The monorail intro seems to go on forever and all the while you can look around and see the many base workers going about their business. It's obviously a very proud Valve showing off their baby and what could be achieved with care and the technology at the time.

As I mentioned earlier, the map was MASSIVE and what's more there were no loading screens whatsoever. An occasional 'loading' indication flashing up which lasts less than a second was all the user was ever presented with. This was totally unheard of back then. Dev's who I worked with at the time were blown away by this and wondering how they'd made a map so big with no loading screens. The lack of loading screens were vital in keeping the 'flow' of the game running smoothly and added to Black Mesa feeling like a an actual immersive 'world' in the truest sense of the word.

Twenty-one years later and this game STILL holds up. It's beautiful, it's absorbing and it's challenging. I recommend any newcomers who are new to this game/franchise, to pick this up. Not just for a nostalgia trip but because it's a major piece of history that everyone who's truly into games should own. 

I myself may pick up the Black Mesa modern remake soon too...

I wasn't even born when Half-Life 1 came out and I was only a few months old when Half-Life 2 came out. So obviously, I only played through the Half-Life games many years after they released, starting with Half-Life 1 and...

It's Half-Life 1. Do I really need to explain why this game is amazing?
The level design, the atmosphere, the great story that doesn't sacrifice gameplay, the puzzles, the great arena-based multiplayer?
Yeah, it's amazing. Although, the graphics have aged very poorly, but for the time, they were amazing.

Even now, the graphics just fit. The poorly textured walls, the dated animations, and the early-3D models aren't a negative of this game. They're a part of the experience of the original Half-Life, which is why I've yet to finish Black Mesa (the fan-remake from 2014). But if the graphics are a big problem for you, then go play Black Mesa.

However, if you DON'T care about graphics...

Oyun ger√ßekten harika! Gerek hikaye, gerek oynanƒ±≈ü, gerek parkur her alanda √ßok etkin bir oyun. Oyunda sinir bozucu b√∂l√ºmler epeyce var fakat kendi i√ßinde bir zevk barƒ±ndƒ±rƒ±yor...

I'd like to say that Half-Life is the engaging masterpiece it was twenty years ago, but now having played it in its entirety, I can't bring myself to lie to you. It's not a horrible game, but the cool design, atmospheric, in-game storytelling and fluid movement hardly make up for unintuitive gameplay and cheap deaths that seem more like an oversight than a conscious choice.

I'd recommend it for those studying the history of the FPS genre as a landmark in narrative-driven shooters, but for those just looking for a fun game, this ain't it.
